slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello and welcome to altera’s online training Using the Nios II Processor: Software Development. My name is Doug and I’ll be the instructor for this session.
In this online training, we will show you the basics how to create and debug software for a Nios II embedded system that you created in Qsys.

The Nios II Embedded Design suite or EDS is a series of cutting edge SW tools, utilities, libraries, and drivers that help you bring you design to market in record time. The Suite includes the Nios II Software Build Tools for Eclipse, Nios II Software Build ToolsCommand line, embedded SW device drivers from Altera, IP and Hardware Abstraction Layer or HAL APIs. The Nios II SW Build tools are fully integrated in to the development environment and they're build from the ground up to be a plugin to the industry standard eclipse GUI. The Nios II SBT focus on improved productivity for large designs and team based designs. The SBT include an integrated development environment including source navigator, editor, debugger, and profiler. They also include a compiler, linker, and assembler for C and C++..

The Nios II Plug in for Eclipse includes a Project manager, Software Templates, the Board Support Package or BSP editor which we'll talk about later. A Flash programmer to allow you to program Flash directly from the software tools and the Quartus II FPGA Programmer.

The Nios II Command Shell is also installed allows you to do command driven SW development. The Nios II SBT incluce a set of powerful commands utilities and scripts to allow you to manage build options for application and BSP and SW libraries, and it is available to you to download from the Altera website 100% free of charge.

The Nios II SBT for Eclipse can be launched through Qsys or through the Windows Program menu. The Gui looks like this. Under the project explorer window any projects that have been created are shown. The file viewer window shows any source files. Files can be edited directly here. The Outline view of the project shows functions, any enumerated types, classes, structures and typedefs associated with the project. The terminal window shows messages that are generated from the build process.




C++ files must have extension .cpp
In-line assembly code offset by asm();

To create a project, the easiest thing to do is use on of the templates. Here I’ve chosen the option to create a new Application and BSP from template. I must specify the SOPCinfo file to provide vital information about the HW system. In this dialog box, I specify project name, and the template I’m using. In this case I’ve chosen the Hello World template.

After creating the project you will see two project directories in the Project Explorer. One for the applicatoin and the other for the BSP.

The application project contains all the source code in your project and the BSP project contains the system header file and links to device driver code.

Right clicking on the BSP project and choosing properties allows the optimization levels to be changed for the board support package files. Also from here we can select reduced size device drivers, small C library and ModelSim simulation support. The BSP editor can be launched from the <click> BSP Project Properties by pressing the BSP editor button. Settings such as Debug level and optimization level are also available for the Application Project.

The BSP Editor allows the user to change more advanced settings in the board support package. The BSP editor consists of tabs across the top of the editor allowing the user to change to different categories in the editor. The settings tab shown here allows the user to change hardware resources for standard in, sout and error devices, the timers associated with sys clk, timestamp timers, and to specify the size and location of the stack. After making changes, be sure to click the generate button to create a new BSP.

Eventually you will have to compile or build your project. In order to do that, you can highlight the application project, <click> right click, and select Build Project... Or you can alternatively go to the project menu and select build project. Doing so will also compile the associated BSP project if needed.

After you compile or build your projects, you’ll find that a number of files have been created inside both your Application project folder and your BSP project folder. For purposes of this training the most important files are outlined here. In the application project, the .elf file contains all of your compiled code and device drivers and gets downloaded to the processor.

In the BSP project, the most important file to remember is the system.h file. This file that contains all of the mappings between the Qsys peripheral names and their base addresses in the memory map. These macros allow you to call out your peripherals by name rather than by specific hex addresses.

After you build your project, you download the code to the processor on your FPGA to run or debug it.
To run code on the target, simply right click on your application project and select Run As Nios II HW. That will download the code through the FPGA programming cable, in through the JTAG ports on the FPGA to the Processor where it will initiate the run sequence.

At run time, the Nios II Eclipse Platform makes sure the SW Matches the HW on the FPGA. It does this by computing the expected System ID peripheral values from the .sopcinfo file and compares to the one in the .sof file.

If computed ID values do not match System ID variables stored on target board then an error is flagged.

You can disable system ID check in the run configuration dialog box, but it’s best to keep it enabled so that the system will flag an error and halt the download process.

The Nios II SBT for Eclipse have a debug perspective useful for debugging your software. Changing to the debug perspective can be done by right-clicking on an application and then selecting debug as Nios II hardware. This will download and run the code on the FPGA in debug mode. The debug perspective can also be set by clicking on the perspective window. In the debug prospective, you can examine the program stack, breakpoints, registers, and memory. Using the Debugger Controls you can suspend or restart the program, or you can step into or over certain lines of code.

This presentation won’t have time to get into all of the software components that are supported by Nios II.

A variety of real tome operating system are supported, including uCOSII which shipped with the kit along with full source code and developer’s license. There are a variety of other Operating systems as well, a variety of middleware, Protocol Stacks for TCP/IP USB etc and a RO file system. The Interniche TCP/IP Stack is shipped with the SW Development Tools an is available for use free of charge. You’ll find a list of all of our SW partners on Altera.com by selecting the embedded processor link then click embedded SW partners.

For additional information on Nios II SW development, check out the NII SW Developer’s Handbook found on altera.com. You can also visth the Nios II sectoin of the altera forum.com, where you’ll find a vibrant discussion for current Nios II Users. Altera Engineers often sign on and answer questions as well.

There is also the Altera Wiki where you’ll find How To Guides and Articles regarding Nios II SW and HW.

A demonstration of the NII Software Build Tools will start shortly. In order to view the demo please ensure that your internet browser popup blocker is disabled. After viewing the demo, please close the demo window and press play to continue the presentation.

(15 seconds)?
As a review, in this presentation, we talked about the embedded SW design tools you can download from Altera, including the Software Build tools for Eclipse.

This online training is only an introduction to software development on the Nios II processor. Altera offers a 2 day Developing Software for the Nios II processor instructor led class to further help you develop your SW system.

Altera offers many other options for training. Our instructor-led training classes are full-day classes taught by experienced training engineers, either in a public class, on-site, or through a virtual classroom. We also feature over 200 free online training classes, just like this one, that allow you to study a topic at your own pace. To find a class, search the course catalog at the Altera training website for any topic discussed in this training. While there, you can register for a free online training or an instructor-led class.

For further information about using the Quartus II software, be sure to check out the online help as well as the Quartus II Handbook. There you’ll find detailed information and multiple examples to help you use all of the features of the Quartus II software effectively. Be sure to check out the Altera web site to find solutions to the most common technical questions and problems, view design examples, and download product literature. You can always visit MySupport to get help from Altera applications engineers or call the hotline to get live assistance. For local assistance, contact your local Altera sales office to speak with a field applications engineer. Check out the Altera wiki for up-to-date articles written by Altera engineers. Finally, the online Altera forums are a great place to connect with other Altera users to share experiences and find solutions to common issues.

One more thing: when you registered for this on-line training, you should have received a link to a short survey where you can provide feedback. We'd greatly appreciate it if you'd fill out that survey now. We're constantly updating and improving our training materials, and your feedback helps us create the materials that you want! Thank you for your feedback. My name is Doug and I want to thank you for taking this online training.
